trans-unit.source: Use Hadoop Sqoop in HDInsight | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Use Hadoop Sqoop in HDInsight | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure PowerShell from a workstation to run Sqoop import and export between an Hadoop cluster and an Azure SQL database.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure PowerShell from a workstation to run Sqoop import and export between an Hadoop cluster and an Azure SQL database.

trans-unit.source: Use Sqoop with Hadoop in HDInsight (Windows)
trans-unit.target: Use Sqoop with Hadoop in HDInsight (Windows)

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure PowerShell and the HDInsight .NET SDK from a workstation to run Sqoop to import and export between an HDInsight cluster and an Azure SQL database or SQL Server database.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure PowerShell and the HDInsight .NET SDK from a workstation to run Sqoop to import and export between an HDInsight cluster and an Azure SQL database or SQL Server database.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The steps in this article can be used with either a Windows-based or Linux-based HDInsight cluster; however, these steps will only work from a Windows client.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The steps in this article can be used with either a Windows-based or Linux-based HDInsight cluster; however, these steps will only work from a Windows client.

trans-unit.source: If you are using a Linux, OS X, or Unix client and a Linux-based HDInsight server, see [Use Sqoop with Hadoop in HDInsight (SSH)](hdinsight-use-sqoop-mac-linux.md)
trans-unit.target: If you are using a Linux, OS X, or Unix client and a Linux-based HDInsight server, see [Use Sqoop with Hadoop in HDInsight (SSH)](hdinsight-use-sqoop-mac-linux.md)

trans-unit.source: What is Sqoop?
trans-unit.target: What is Sqoop?

trans-unit.source: Although Hadoop is a natural choice for processing unstructured and semistructured data, such as logs and files, there may also be a need to process structured data that is stored in relational databases.
trans-unit.target: Although Hadoop is a natural choice for processing unstructured and semistructured data, such as logs and files, there may also be a need to process structured data that is stored in relational databases.

trans-unit.source: [Sqoop][sqoop-user-guide-1.4.4] is a tool designed to transfer data between Hadoop clusters and relational databases.
trans-unit.target: [Sqoop][sqoop-user-guide-1.4.4] is a tool designed to transfer data between Hadoop clusters and relational databases.

trans-unit.source: You can use it to import data from a relational database management system (RDBMS) such as SQL Server, MySQL, or Oracle into the Hadoop distributed file system (HDFS), transform the data in Hadoop with MapReduce or Hive, and then export the data back into an RDBMS.
trans-unit.target: You can use it to import data from a relational database management system (RDBMS) such as SQL Server, MySQL, or Oracle into the Hadoop distributed file system (HDFS), transform the data in Hadoop with MapReduce or Hive, and then export the data back into an RDBMS.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you are using a SQL Server database for your relational database.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you are using a SQL Server database for your relational database.

trans-unit.source: For Sqoop versions that are supported on HDInsight clusters, see [What's new in the cluster versions provided by HDInsight?][hdinsight-versions].
trans-unit.target: For Sqoop versions that are supported on HDInsight clusters, see [What's new in the cluster versions provided by HDInsight?][hdinsight-versions].

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Before you begin this tutorial, you must have the following:
trans-unit.target: Before you begin this tutorial, you must have the following:

trans-unit.source: **A workstation with Azure PowerShell**.
trans-unit.target: **A workstation with Azure PowerShell**.

trans-unit.source: See [Install and use Azure PowerShell](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/videos/install-and-use-azure-powershell/).
trans-unit.target: See [Install and use Azure PowerShell](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/videos/install-and-use-azure-powershell/).

trans-unit.source: To execute Azure PowerShell scripts, you must run Azure PowerShell as an administrator and set the execution policy to *RemoteSigned*.
trans-unit.target: To execute Azure PowerShell scripts, you must run Azure PowerShell as an administrator and set the execution policy to *RemoteSigned*.

trans-unit.source: See [Run Windows PowerShell scripts][powershell-script].
trans-unit.target: See [Run Windows PowerShell scripts][powershell-script].

trans-unit.source: **Azure HDInsight cluster**: For instructions about cluster provision, see [Get started using HDInsight][hdinsight-get-started] or [Provision HDInsight clusters][hdinsight-provision].
trans-unit.target: **Azure HDInsight cluster**: For instructions about cluster provision, see [Get started using HDInsight][hdinsight-get-started] or [Provision HDInsight clusters][hdinsight-provision].

trans-unit.source: You need the following data to go through the tutorial:
trans-unit.target: You need the following data to go through the tutorial:

trans-unit.target: Cluster property

trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell variable name

trans-unit.target: HDInsight cluster name

trans-unit.target: $clusterName

trans-unit.source: Your HDInsight cluster name.
trans-unit.target: Your HDInsight cluster name.

trans-unit.target: Azure Storage account name

trans-unit.source: $storageAccountName
trans-unit.target: $storageAccountName

trans-unit.source: An Azure Storage account that is available to the HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: An Azure Storage account that is available to the HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial, use the default storage account that you specified during the cluster provisioning process.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial, use the default storage account that you specified during the cluster provisioning process.

trans-unit.source: Azure blob container name
trans-unit.target: Azure blob container name

trans-unit.source: $containerName
trans-unit.target: $containerName

trans-unit.source: For this example, use the name of the blob that is used for the default HDInsight cluster file system.
trans-unit.target: For this example, use the name of the blob that is used for the default HDInsight cluster file system.

trans-unit.source: By default, it has the same name as the HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: By default, it has the same name as the HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: **Azure SQL database**: You must configure a firewall rule for the Azure SQL database server to allow access from your workstation.
trans-unit.target: **Azure SQL database**: You must configure a firewall rule for the Azure SQL database server to allow access from your workstation.

trans-unit.source: For instructions about creating an Azure SQL database and configuring the firewall, see [Get started using Azure SQL database][sqldatabase-get-started].
trans-unit.target: For instructions about creating an Azure SQL database and configuring the firewall, see [Get started using Azure SQL database][sqldatabase-get-started].

trans-unit.source: This article provides a Windows PowerShell script for creating the Azure SQL database table that you need for this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: This article provides a Windows PowerShell script for creating the Azure SQL database table that you need for this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] By default an Azure SQL database allows connections from Azure services, such as Azure HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] By default an Azure SQL database allows connections from Azure services, such as Azure HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: If this firewall setting is disabled, you must enabled it from the Azure preview portal.
trans-unit.target: If this firewall setting is disabled, you must enabled it from the Azure preview portal.

trans-unit.source: For instruction about creating an Azure SQL database and configuring firewall rules, see [Create and Configure SQL Database][sqldatabase-create-configue].
trans-unit.target: For instruction about creating an Azure SQL database and configuring firewall rules, see [Create and Configure SQL Database][sqldatabase-create-configue].

trans-unit.source: **SQL Server**: If your HDInsight cluster is on the same virtual network in Azure as SQL Server, you can use the steps in this article to import and export data to a SQL Server database.
trans-unit.target: **SQL Server**: If your HDInsight cluster is on the same virtual network in Azure as SQL Server, you can use the steps in this article to import and export data to a SQL Server database.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] HDInsight supports only location-based virtual networks, and it does not currently work with affinity group-based virtual networks.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] HDInsight supports only location-based virtual networks, and it does not currently work with affinity group-based virtual networks.

trans-unit.source: To create and configure a virtual network, see [Virtual Network Configuration Tasks](../services/virtual-machines/).
trans-unit.target: To create and configure a virtual network, see [Virtual Network Configuration Tasks](../services/virtual-machines/).

trans-unit.source: When you are using SQL Server in your datacenter, you must configure the virtual network as *site-to-site* or *point-to-site*.
trans-unit.target: When you are using SQL Server in your datacenter, you must configure the virtual network as *site-to-site* or *point-to-site*.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] For **point-to-site** virtual networks, SQL Server must be running the VPN client configuration application, which is available from the **Dashboard** of your Azure virtual network configuration.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] For **point-to-site** virtual networks, SQL Server must be running the VPN client configuration application, which is available from the **Dashboard** of your Azure virtual network configuration.

trans-unit.source: When you are using SQL Server on an Azure virtual machine, any virtual network configuration can be used if the virtual machine hosting SQL Server is a member of the same virtual network as HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: When you are using SQL Server on an Azure virtual machine, any virtual network configuration can be used if the virtual machine hosting SQL Server is a member of the same virtual network as HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: To provision an HDInsight cluster on a virtual network, see [Provision Hadoop clusters in HDInsight using custom options](hdinsight-provision-clusters.md)
trans-unit.target: To provision an HDInsight cluster on a virtual network, see [Provision Hadoop clusters in HDInsight using custom options](hdinsight-provision-clusters.md)

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] SQL Server must also allow authentication.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] SQL Server must also allow authentication.

trans-unit.source: You must use a SQL Server login to complete the steps in this article.
trans-unit.target: You must use a SQL Server login to complete the steps in this article.

trans-unit.source: You will first export *sample.log* and *hivesampletable* to the Azure SQL database or to SQL Server, and then import the table that contains the mobile device data back to HDInsight by using the following path:

trans-unit.source: Understand HDInsight storage
trans-unit.target: Understand HDInsight storage

trans-unit.source: HDInsight uses Azure Blob storage for data storage.
trans-unit.target: HDInsight uses Azure Blob storage for data storage.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Use Azure Blob storage with HDInsight][hdinsight-storage].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Use Azure Blob storage with HDInsight][hdinsight-storage].

trans-unit.source: When you provision an HDInsight cluster, an Azure Storage account and a specific blob storage container from that account are designated as the default file system, like in HDFS.
trans-unit.target: When you provision an HDInsight cluster, an Azure Storage account and a specific blob storage container from that account are designated as the default file system, like in HDFS.

trans-unit.source: In addition to this storage account, you can add additional storage accounts from the same Azure subscription or from different Azure subscriptions during the provision process.
trans-unit.target: In addition to this storage account, you can add additional storage accounts from the same Azure subscription or from different Azure subscriptions during the provision process.

trans-unit.source: For instructions about adding additional storage accounts, see [Provision HDInsight clusters][hdinsight-provision].
trans-unit.target: For instructions about adding additional storage accounts, see [Provision HDInsight clusters][hdinsight-provision].

trans-unit.source: To simply the Windows PowerShell script used in this tutorial, all of the files are stored in the default file system container located at */tutorials/usesqoop*.
trans-unit.target: To simply the Windows PowerShell script used in this tutorial, all of the files are stored in the default file system container located at */tutorials/usesqoop*.

trans-unit.source: By default, this container has the same name as the HDInsight cluster name.
trans-unit.target: By default, this container has the same name as the HDInsight cluster name.

trans-unit.source: The syntax is:
trans-unit.target: The syntax is:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Only the *wasb://* syntax is supported in HDInsight cluster version 3.0.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Only the *wasb://* syntax is supported in HDInsight cluster version 3.0.

trans-unit.source: The older *asv://* syntax is supported in HDInsight 2.1 and 1.6 clusters, but it is not supported in HDInsight 3.0 clusters.
trans-unit.target: The older *asv://* syntax is supported in HDInsight 2.1 and 1.6 clusters, but it is not supported in HDInsight 3.0 clusters.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The *wasb://* path is a virtual path.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The *wasb://* path is a virtual path.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Use Azure Blob storage with HDInsight][hdinsight-storage].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Use Azure Blob storage with HDInsight][hdinsight-storage].

trans-unit.source: A file that is stored in the default file system blob can be accessed from HDInsight by using any of the following URIs (the following examples use sample.log):
trans-unit.target: A file that is stored in the default file system blob can be accessed from HDInsight by using any of the following URIs (the following examples use sample.log):

trans-unit.source: If you want to access the file directly from the storage account, the blob name for the file is:
trans-unit.target: If you want to access the file directly from the storage account, the blob name for the file is:

trans-unit.source: Prepare the tutorial
trans-unit.target: Prepare the tutorial

trans-unit.source: You will create two tables in the Azure SQL database or in SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: You will create two tables in the Azure SQL database or in SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: These are used by Sqoop to export later in the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: These are used by Sqoop to export later in the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: You also need to process the sample.log files before they can be processed by Sqoop.
trans-unit.target: You also need to process the sample.log files before they can be processed by Sqoop.

trans-unit.target: Create a SQL tables

trans-unit.source: For an Azure SQL database
trans-unit.target: For an Azure SQL database

trans-unit.source: Open the Windows PowerShell ISE (on the Start screen in Windows 8, type **PowerShell_ISE**, and then click **Windows PowerShell ISE**.
trans-unit.target: Open the Windows PowerShell ISE (on the Start screen in Windows 8, type **PowerShell_ISE**, and then click **Windows PowerShell ISE**.

trans-unit.source: See [Start Windows PowerShell on Windows 8 and Windows][powershell-start]).
trans-unit.target: See [Start Windows PowerShell on Windows 8 and Windows][powershell-start]).

trans-unit.source: Copy the following script into the script pane, and then set the first four variables:
trans-unit.target: Copy the following script into the script pane, and then set the first four variables:

trans-unit.target: For more descriptions of the variables, see the [Prerequisites](#prerequisites) section in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Append the following script in the script pane.
trans-unit.target: Append the following script in the script pane.

trans-unit.source: These are the SQL statements that define the two tables and their clustered indexes.
trans-unit.target: These are the SQL statements that define the two tables and their clustered indexes.

trans-unit.source: The Azure SQL database requires a clustered index.
trans-unit.target: The Azure SQL database requires a clustered index.

trans-unit.source: Append the following script in the script pane to run the SQL commands:
trans-unit.target: Append the following script in the script pane to run the SQL commands:

trans-unit.source: Click **Run Script** or press **F5** to run the script.
trans-unit.target: Click **Run Script** or press **F5** to run the script.

trans-unit.source: Use the [preview portal][azure-management-portal] to examine the tables and clustered indexes.
trans-unit.target: Use the [preview portal][azure-management-portal] to examine the tables and clustered indexes.

trans-unit.source: For SQL Server
trans-unit.target: For SQL Server

trans-unit.source: Open **SQL Server Management Studio** and connect to SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: Open **SQL Server Management Studio** and connect to SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: Create a new database named **sqoopdb**.
trans-unit.target: Create a new database named **sqoopdb**.

trans-unit.source: Select the **sqoopdb** database, and then select **New query** from the ribbon at the top of SQL Server Management Studio.
trans-unit.target: Select the **sqoopdb** database, and then select **New query** from the ribbon at the top of SQL Server Management Studio.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following information in the query window:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following information in the query window:

trans-unit.source: Click **F5**, or select **! Execute** on the ribbon to run the query.
trans-unit.target: Click **F5**, or select **! Execute** on the ribbon to run the query.

trans-unit.source: The following message should appear under the query:
trans-unit.target: The following message should appear under the query:

trans-unit.source: Close SQL Server Management Studio.
trans-unit.target: Close SQL Server Management Studio.

trans-unit.source: Generate data
trans-unit.target: Generate data

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will export a log4j log file (a delimited file) and a Hive table to an Azure SQL database.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will export a log4j log file (a delimited file) and a Hive table to an Azure SQL database.

trans-unit.source: The delimited file is called */example/data/sample.log*.
trans-unit.target: The delimited file is called */example/data/sample.log*.

trans-unit.source: Earlier in the tutorial, you saw a few samples of log4j logs.
trans-unit.target: Earlier in the tutorial, you saw a few samples of log4j logs.

trans-unit.source: In the log file, there are some empty lines and some lines similar to these:
trans-unit.target: In the log file, there are some empty lines and some lines similar to these:

trans-unit.source: This is fine for other examples that use this data, but we must remove these exceptions before we can import into the Azure SQL database or SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: This is fine for other examples that use this data, but we must remove these exceptions before we can import into the Azure SQL database or SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: Sqoop export will fail if there is an empty string or a line with a fewer number of elements than the number of fields defined in the Azure SQL database table.
trans-unit.target: Sqoop export will fail if there is an empty string or a line with a fewer number of elements than the number of fields defined in the Azure SQL database table.

trans-unit.source: The log4jlogs table has 7 string-type fields.
trans-unit.target: The log4jlogs table has 7 string-type fields.

trans-unit.source: To process the sample.log file
trans-unit.target: To process the sample.log file

trans-unit.source: Open the Windows PowerShell ISE.
trans-unit.target: Open the Windows PowerShell ISE.

trans-unit.target: In the bottom pane, run the following command to connect to your Azure subscription:

trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to enter your Azure account credentials.

trans-unit.source: This method of adding a subscription connection times out, and after 12 hours, you will have to log in again.
trans-unit.target: This method of adding a subscription connection times out, and after 12 hours, you will have to log in again.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you have multiple Azure subscriptions and the default subscription is not the one you want to use, use the Select-AzureSubscription cmdlet to select the current subscription.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you have multiple Azure subscriptions and the default subscription is not the one you want to use, use the Select-AzureSubscription cmdlet to select the current subscription.

trans-unit.source: To examine the modified data file, you can use the preview portal, an Azure Storage explorer tool, or Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: To examine the modified data file, you can use the preview portal, an Azure Storage explorer tool, or Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: [Get started with HDInsight][hdinsight-get-started] has a code sample for using Azure PowerShell to download a file and display the file content.
trans-unit.target: [Get started with HDInsight][hdinsight-get-started] has a code sample for using Azure PowerShell to download a file and display the file content.

trans-unit.source: Use PowerShell to run Sqoop export
trans-unit.target: Use PowerShell to run Sqoop export

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will use Azure PowerShell to run the Sqoop export command to export a Hive table and a data file to an Azure SQL database or to SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will use Azure PowerShell to run the Sqoop export command to export a Hive table and a data file to an Azure SQL database or to SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: The next section provides an HDInsight .NET sample.
trans-unit.target: The next section provides an HDInsight .NET sample.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Other than connection string information, the steps in this section should work for an Azure SQL database or for SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Other than connection string information, the steps in this section should work for an Azure SQL database or for SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: These steps were tested by using the following configuration:
trans-unit.target: These steps were tested by using the following configuration:

trans-unit.source: **Azure virtual network point-to-site configuration**: A virtual network connected the HDInsight cluster to a SQL Server in a private datacenter.
trans-unit.target: **Azure virtual network point-to-site configuration**: A virtual network connected the HDInsight cluster to a SQL Server in a private datacenter.

trans-unit.source: See [Configure a Point-to-Site VPN in the Management Portal](../vpn-gateway/vpn-gateway-point-to-site-create.md) for more information.
trans-unit.target: See [Configure a Point-to-Site VPN in the Management Portal](../vpn-gateway/vpn-gateway-point-to-site-create.md) for more information.

trans-unit.source: **Azure HDInsight 3.1**: See [Provision Hadoop clusters in HDInsight using custom options](hdinsight-provision-clusters.md) for information about creating a cluster on a virtual network.
trans-unit.target: **Azure HDInsight 3.1**: See [Provision Hadoop clusters in HDInsight using custom options](hdinsight-provision-clusters.md) for information about creating a cluster on a virtual network.

trans-unit.source: **SQL Server 2014**: Configured to allow authentication and running the VPN client configuration package to connect securely to the virtual network.
trans-unit.target: **SQL Server 2014**: Configured to allow authentication and running the VPN client configuration package to connect securely to the virtual network.

trans-unit.source: To export the log4j log file
trans-unit.target: To export the log4j log file

trans-unit.source: Open the Windows PowerShell ISE.
trans-unit.target: Open the Windows PowerShell ISE.

trans-unit.source: In the bottom pane, run the following command to connect to your Azure subscription:
trans-unit.target: In the bottom pane, run the following command to connect to your Azure subscription:

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to enter your Azure account credentials.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to enter your Azure account credentials.

trans-unit.source: Copy the following script into the script pane, and then set the first seven variables:
trans-unit.target: Copy the following script into the script pane, and then set the first seven variables:

trans-unit.source: For more descriptions of the variables, see the [Prerequisites](#prerequisites) section in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: For more descriptions of the variables, see the [Prerequisites](#prerequisites) section in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Notice that $exportDir_log4j doesn't have the sample.log file file name specified.
trans-unit.target: Notice that $exportDir_log4j doesn't have the sample.log file file name specified.

trans-unit.source: Sqoop will export the data from all of the files under that folder.
trans-unit.target: Sqoop will export the data from all of the files under that folder.

trans-unit.source: Append the following script in the script pane:
trans-unit.target: Append the following script in the script pane:

trans-unit.source: Notice that the field delimiter is **\0x20**, which is space.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the field delimiter is **\0x20**, which is space.

trans-unit.source: The delimiter is defined in the sample.log file Azure PowerShell script.
trans-unit.target: The delimiter is defined in the sample.log file Azure PowerShell script.

trans-unit.source: To find out about **-m 1**, see [Sqoop User Guide][sqoop-user-guide-1.4.4].
trans-unit.target: To find out about **-m 1**, see [Sqoop User Guide][sqoop-user-guide-1.4.4].

trans-unit.source: Click **Run Script** or press **F5** to run the script.
trans-unit.target: Click **Run Script** or press **F5** to run the script.

trans-unit.source: Use the [preview portal][azure-management-portal] to examine the exported data.
trans-unit.target: Use the [preview portal][azure-management-portal] to examine the exported data.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: Now you have learned how to use Sqoop.
trans-unit.target: Now you have learned how to use Sqoop.

trans-unit.target: To learn more, see:

trans-unit.source: [Use Oozie with HDInsight][hdinsight-use-oozie]: Use Sqoop action in an Oozie workflow.
trans-unit.target: [Use Oozie with HDInsight][hdinsight-use-oozie]: Use Sqoop action in an Oozie workflow.

trans-unit.source: [Analyze flight delay data using HDInsight][hdinsight-analyze-flight-data]: Use Hive to analyze flight delay data, and then use Sqoop to export data to an Azure SQL database.
trans-unit.target: [Analyze flight delay data using HDInsight][hdinsight-analyze-flight-data]: Use Hive to analyze flight delay data, and then use Sqoop to export data to an Azure SQL database.
